metadata.sermon_start_end: In the years long ago, when I grew up in the Louisiana swamp country, my elders talked with almost bated breath about something which had happened, oh, eighteen, twenty years earlier. They spoke about it hardly with full belief, for many of them had known the dark night of slavery. [...] Standing in the light of that promise, we may believe in some clear day, unclouded by pride and prejudice, when every valley of disparity will be lifted up, when every mountain of obstacle will be brought down, when every crooked way of deception will be straightened out, when every rough place of delay will be removed, and all flesh shall see it, to the glory of God. We see a better, a brighter, a more glorious day in this land which God has given us all. 'Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord. Glory, glory, hallelujah, his truth is marching on.'

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Luke 10:25-28 as a springboard for a civil religion discourse rather than treating it as a unique, current, proclamatory word. The preacher fails to identify what is in this specific passage that can be found nowhere else. Instead, the text is used to validate the 'American proposition'.
quotes: Let me seek briefly now my footing in the Word of God.
This parable Jesus relates at this meeting has come to be called the parable of the good Samaritan.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Cease using the Scripture as 'footing' for political commentary and instead treat the text as the primary subject that must 'expound' the audience.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Greek/Hebrew scholarship or historical-critical depth. The 'lawyer' is treated as a modern 'craft' rather than a first-century legal expert in the Torah. The original context of the lawyer's 'tempting' of Jesus is ignored in favor of a general philosophical inquiry.
quotes: A lawyer, appropriately enough, asked the question, and I take it that that craft is not underrepresented here today.
The questioner goes back into the long, bright engagement of Israel with divine truth...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific tension between the lawyer's intent and Jesus' subversion of the Law's boundaries in the first-century Jewish context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is highly concrete regarding the American political situation (Clinton/Gore inauguration), but it is a socio-political application rather than a theological one derived from the text. It borders on general truths about democracy rather than the specific demand of the Gospel.
quotes: This is the American proposition in history.
Do you sense, as I do quite often, that this nation represents something new and promising and purposeful in history?
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift application from the 'American idea' to the concrete spiritual and ethical demands the text makes on the individual and the church.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of anecdotes and political reflections with the Bible text inserted in the middle. The text does not drive the movement; the 'zeitgeist' (the inauguration) drives the text. The hearer is not drawn into the text, but the text is pulled into the American narrative.
quotes: A lawyer meets a savior. Across the broad face of this land there is a sense today... of a new energy.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the logic of the biblical passage to dictate the structure of the sermon rather than using it as an interlude between political observations.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is identified as the 'stain' of slavery and the 'plague' (AIDS), but it is framed more as a national struggle than a theological state before God. Redemption is conflated with national progress. Gratitude is present but directed toward the 'American proposition'.
quotes: ...the splendor and the squalor, the grandeur and the grime...
They believed that time and God and the intent of the nation would erase the stain...
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Clarify that misery is 'before God' and redemption is 'through Christ', not through the evolution of democratic institutions.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are almost entirely absent. The sermon is overwhelmingly optimistic ('springtime in America'). The possibility of being 'lost' is mentioned only as 'treason against the idea of America', which is a secularization of the theological concept.
quotes: ...anybody who speaks or acts against that purpose... comes close to committing treason against the idea of America.
It is as if we have come again to Camelot...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the radical alternative of the Gospel: that failing to 'do this' (love) leads to actual loss, not just political failure.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as 'Savior' and 'Lord', but he is not the telos. The telos of the sermon is the 'bright tomorrow' of a unified America. The doctrine of the two natures is not utilized; Christ functions more as a teacher of a universal triangle of love.
quotes: ...so that it is really a triangle: 'thou shalt love the Lord thy God, and thy neighbor as thyself'...
Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the goal of the sermon by showing how He alone fulfills the Law that the lawyer (and we) cannot.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14.5 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's minimum requirement of 20 minutes. It lacks the 'breadth' required for theological 'depth', opting instead for rhetorical flourishes and patriotic sentiment.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the duration by deepening the exegetical and dogmatic analysis of the text's specific demands.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls significantly short of Dekker's criteria, primarily because it subordinates the Word of God to the 'American proposition'. It functions as a piece of civil rhetoric rather than a theological exposition. The specific Bible passage is treated as a secondary 'footing' for a discussion on national identity. The seriousness of the 'two ways' is replaced by an optimistic 'Camelot' narrative, and the duration is insufficient for the depth Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete contemporary relevance regarding the political climate and social history.
Strong psychological awareness of the 'raw nerve of human existence' and the difficulty of self-love.
weaknesses: Theologically thin; replaces the Kingdom of God with the American Republic.
Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) prevents necessary theological breadth.
Lack of specific exegesis; the preacher ignores the unique nuances of the Lukan text.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a socio-political speech with biblical ornamentation. It fails to recreate the Bible into a 'new, current, proclamatory word' that stands over and against the world, choosing instead to baptize the zeitgeist.
